features.name: backbone
features.question: Does the animal have a backbone, spine, or notochord?

features.name: skeleton
features.question: Does the animal have an internal skeleton (or notochord) made of bone or cartilage?

features.name: skull
features.question: Does the animal have a head with a brain protected by a skull?

features.name: lack of tissues and organs
features.question: Does the animal lack true tissues or organs?

features.name: pores
features.question: Does the animal have a porous body with many small holes (pores)?

features.name: also lives in fresh water
features.question: Can the animal be found in fresh water?

features.name: milk feeding
features.question: Does the animal produce milk (NOT crop milk) to feed its young?

features.name: warm blooded
features.question: Does the animal have a constant body temperature (warm-blooded)?

features.name: hair fur
features.question: Does the animal have fur or hair?

features.name: underdeveloped young
features.question: Does the animal give birth to underdeveloped young that crawl into a pouch?

features.name: pouch
features.question: Does the animal have a pouch where the young develop after birth?

features.name: live birth
features.question: Does the animal give live birth (i.e., do the offspring develop inside the mother and are born alive, rather than hatching from eggs)?

features.name: fully developed young
features.question: Does the animal give birth to fully developed young (i.e., those that do not require nurturing outside the womb, such as in a pouch)?

features.name: placenta
features.question: Does the animal have a placenta to nourish the young during gestation (between conception and birth)?

features.name: chewing
features.question: Does the animal have specialized teeth for chewing or grinding food?

features.name: lay eggs
features.question: Does the animal lay eggs instead of giving live birth?

features.name: specialized glands
features.question: Does the animal have specialized mammary glands for producing milk, but no nipples?

features.name: live in water
features.question: Does the animal primarily live in water or burrow underground?

features.name: fins
features.question: Does the animal have fins instead of legs?

features.name: gills
features.question: Does the animal breathe with gills?

features.name: in water
features.question: Does the animal live in water?

features.name: sucker-like or slit-like mouth
features.question: Does the fish lack a jaw and have a round, sucker-like or slit-like mouth instead of teeth?

features.name: looks like an eel
features.question: Does it look like an eel, with smooth skin and no visible scales?

features.name: slim, elongated body
features.question: Does the fish have a slim, elongated body and appear to be more primitive compared to other fish?

features.name: feels rough like sandpaper
features.question: Does the fish have visible fins and jaws but feel rough like sandpaper, or seem to have no hard bones?

features.name: looks like a shark
features.question: Does it look like a shark, ray, or skate?

features.name: long, cylindrical body
features.question: Does the fish have a long, cylindrical body and appear to swim using side-to-side motions?

features.name: hard bones, shiny scales
features.question: Does the fish look like it has hard bones, scales that are smooth or shiny, and a wide variety of body shapes?

features.name: looks like common fish
features.question: Does it look like most common fish you would see in aquariums or when fishing?

features.name: streamlined or symmetrical body
features.question: Does the fish have a more streamlined or symmetrical body and often appear in schools or large groups?

features.name: both water land
features.question: Does the animal live both in water and on land at different stages of its life?

features.name: larva born
features.question: Does the animal start life as a larva or tadpole in water?

features.name: eggs in water
features.question: Does the animal lay eggs in water?

features.name: scaly skin
features.question: Does the animal have dry, scaly skin?

features.name: lungs
features.question: Does the animal breathe using lungs its entire life?

features.name: leathery eggs
features.question: Does the animal lay leathery or soft-shell eggs?

features.name: feathers
features.question: Does the animal have feathers?

features.name: beak
features.question: Does the animal have a beak or bill instead of teeth?

features.name: eggs hard shell
features.question: Does the animal lay eggs with hard shells?

features.name: unsegmented body
features.question: Does the animal have a soft, unsegmented body?

features.name: tentacles
features.question: Does the animal have a muscular foot or tentacles for movement?

features.name: mantle
features.question: Does the animal have a mantle (a tissue layer) that secretes a shell or protects internal organs?

features.name: segmented body
features.question: Does the animal have a segmented body?

features.name: jointed legs
features.question: Does the animal have jointed legs or appendages?

features.name: exoskeleton
features.question: Does the animal have an exoskeleton made of chitin?

features.name: aquatic
features.question: Does the animal live primarily in aquatic environments?

features.name: pairs of antennae
features.question: Does the animal have two pairs of antennae?

features.name: carapace
features.question: Does the animal have a hard exoskeleton (often called a carapace) covering its body?

features.name: segmented body with numerous legs
features.question: Does the animal have a long, segmented body with numerous legs?

features.name: pair of legs per segment
features.question: Does the animal have one or two pair of legs per segment

features.name: fangs or small mandibles
features.question: Does the animal have large fangs (for injecting venom) or smaller mandibles for grinding vegetation?

features.name: two segments
features.question: Does the animal have a body divided into two main segments (cephalothorax and abdomen)?

features.name: eight legs
features.question: Does the animal have four pairs of legs (eight legs total)?

features.name: pedipalps
features.question: Does the animal have specialized appendages called pedipalps near the mouth?

features.name: three segments
features.question: Does the animal have a body divided into three main segments: head, thorax, and abdomen?

features.name: six legs
features.question: Does the animal have three pairs of legs (six legs total)?

features.name: compound eyes and antennae
features.question: Does the animal have compound eyes and one pair of antennae?

features.name: endoskeleton
features.question: Does the animal have an endoskeleton made of ossicles?

features.name: water vascular system
features.question: Does the animal have a water vascular system?

features.name: radial symmetry
features.question: Does the animal have radial symmetry?

features.name: cnidocytes
features.question: Does the animal have stinging cells (cnidocytes)?

features.name: sac-like
features.question: Does the animal have a sac-like body with a single opening for food and waste?

features.name: sessile
features.question: Is the animal sessile (fixed in one place) for its entire life?

features.name: reefs
features.question: Does the animal form colonies that build reefs?

features.name: get energy from tiny plants
features.question: Does the animal get energy from tiny plants (algae) that live inside its body and help it make food?

features.name: freshwater
features.question: Does the animal live in freshwater (like lakes, rivers, or ponds) instead of the ocean?

features.name: regenerate
features.question: Does the animal regenerate when cut into pieces?

features.name: stay in one place
features.question: Does the animal stay in one place, attached to a surface (polyplop form), for its whole life instead of swimming freely?

features.name: bell-shaped
features.question: Does the animal have a bell-shaped medusa body form?

features.name: float-freely
features.question: Does the animal float freely in water currents?

features.name: stinging cells
features.question: Does the animal have tentacles with stinging cells used to capture prey?

features.name: unsegmented or segmented body
features.question: Does the animal have a long, soft body that is either unsegmented or segmented?

features.name: bilateral symmetry
features.question: Does the animal have bilateral symmetry?

features.name: lacks legs or appendages
features.question: Does the animal lack legs or appendages?

features.name: dorsoventrally flattened
features.question: Is the animal dorsoventrally flattened (flat body)?

features.name: lacks body cavity
features.question: Does the animal lack a body cavity (acoelomate)?

features.name: relies on diffusion for gas exchange
features.question: Does the animal rely on diffusion for gas exchange and waste removal?

features.name: cylindrical, unsegmented body
features.question: Does the animal have a cylindrical, unsegmented body?

features.name: complete digestive tract
features.question: Does the animal have a complete digestive tract with a separate mouth and anus?

features.name: parasite in mammals
features.question: Does the animal usually live as a parasite in the digestive system of mammals?

features.name: segmented body divided into repeating sections
features.question: Does the animal have a segmented body divided into repeating sections, like rings or segments?

features.name: circulatory system with blood vessels
features.question: Does the animal have a circulatory system with blood vessels?

features.name: tiny hair-like structures
features.question: Does the animal have tiny hair-like structures on its body that help it move?

required features: relies on diffusion for gas exchange

Rules.end classification:
The animal is classified as a flatworm.
 Invertebrates → Worms → Flatworms

The animal is classified as a roundworm.
 Invertebrates → Worms → Roundworms

required features: segmented body divided into repeating sections

Rules.end classification:
The animal is classified as a segmented worm.
 Invertebrates → Worms → Segmented Worms

The animal cannot be classified into a subgroup based on your current answers. You may restart the program and try again with different answers.

 Invertebrates → Arthropods → Insects

Instructions:
Welcome to the Animal Classification System!
This system will help you classify the animal you have in mind into one of the groups shown on the classification tree (accessible via the 'Tree' button). You will be asked a series of yes/no questions about the animal's features. If you make a mistake, do not worry, you can restart the process at any time.
An 'Open Dictionary' button is available at the top right corner to help you understand any unfamiliar biological terms. Please keep in mind that the system may not always be accurate and cannot classify every possible animal. In some cases, the system may not be able to determine a specific class or subgroup, but it will still provide the best possible classification group.
Throughout the classification process, updates will be displayed at the top left corner of the page. Once completed, you will receive a classification message along with example images of animals from that group. Hovering over the images will reveal a fun surprise!
If you wish to stop at any time, simply click the 'X' at the top right of the page to exit the program.
You can always access these instructions by clicking the question mark button at the top right corner.
We hope you enjoy using the system and that it proves helpful in your animal classification journey!

Dictionary.Definition: An animal that lacks a body cavity (coelom). Example: flatworms.
A body plan where the left and right sides of the body are mirror images of each other.
A hard outer shell that protects some animals, like crabs or turtles.
A flexible connective tissue found in animals, often in their skeletons.
A body region in some arthropods that combines the head and thorax into one part.
Specialized stinging cells found in coelenterates like jellyfish.
A system of organs in animals that processes food, typically including a mouth and anus.
The process by which molecules move from an area of higher concentration to lower concentration.
An internal skeleton made of bone or cartilage, found in vertebrates and echinoderms.
A hard, external covering or shell that supports and protects the body of some animals.
An immature stage in the life cycle of an animal that undergoes metamorphosis.
A tissue layer in mollusks that secretes the shell and protects internal organs.
A biological process in which an animal changes its body form during its life cycle.
A specialized cell containing a barbed or venomous coiled thread in cnidarians like jellyfish.
A flexible rod-like structure that supports the body in all embryonic and some adult chordates.
Small calcareous plates that make up the endoskeleton of echinoderms.
An organ in placental mammals that nourishes the fetus during gestation.
A body plan where parts are arranged around a central axis, as in jellyfish and starfish.
The ability to regrow lost or damaged body parts.
Describes an organism that is fixed in one place and does not move.
Specialized cells in cnidarians used for capturing prey and defense, containing nematocysts.
The balanced arrangement of body parts on either side of a dividing line or around a central point.
Flexible, elongated structures used for grasping, feeding, or sensory purposes in some animals.
A system of tubes in plants or animals for transporting fluids like blood or water.
Animals with a backbone or spinal column.

Images.Name: Cat
Images.Fact: Cats have been to space.

Images.Name: Capybara
Images.Fact: Adult capybaras weigh as much as adult humans.

Images.Name: Axolotl
Images.Fact: Axolotls can regrow their own body parts.

Images.Name: Housefly
Images.Fact: Houseflies can taste with their feet.

Images.Name: Sponge
Images.Fact: Sponges lack a nervous system, but can coordinate their activities.

Images.Name: Lobster
Images.Fact: Lobsters have teeth in their stomachs.

Images.Name: Walrus
Images.Fact: Walrus calves are born weighing about 85 kg.

Images.Name: Orca
Images.Fact: Orcas are pregnant for 17 months.

Images.Name: Squirrel
Images.Fact: Squirrels unintentionally plant new trees.

Images.Name: Platypus
Images.Fact: Platypuses are venomous.

Images.Name: Short-beaked echidna
Images.Fact: They can grow up to 40 cm.

Images.Name: Eastern long-beaked echidna
Images.Fact: They can roll into a spiny ball for defense.

Images.Name: Quokka
Images.Fact: Known as the happiest animal in the world.

Images.Name: Kangaroo
Images.Fact: Most kangaroos are left-handed.

Images.Name: Koala
Images.Fact: Koalas sleep up to 20 hours a day.

Images.Name: Horse
Images.Fact: In 2003, a mare was cloned in Italy.

Images.Name: Dog
Images.Fact: Dogs poop aligned with Earth's magnetic field.

Images.Name: Leopard
Images.Fact: When hunting, the tip of a leopard's tail may twitch.

Images.Name: King mackerel
Images.Fact: They can be 1.7 meters long and 45 kg heavy.

Images.Name: Butterfly ray
Images.Fact: They can grow up to 4 meters wide.

Images.Name: Comet-tailed goldfish
Images.Fact: They can recognize their owners.

Images.Name: Lamprey
Images.Fact: They can survive without eating for up to a year.

Images.Name: Hagfish
Images.Fact: They have four hearts.

Images.Name: Tully monster
Images.Fact: Lived around 300 million years ago.

Images.Name: Great white shark
Images.Fact: Can detect one drop of blood in 95 liters of water.

Images.Name: Manta ray
Images.Fact: Smaller fish clean parasites from their bodies.

Images.Name: Skate
Images.Fact: Can regenerate lost fins over time.

Images.Name: Clownfish
Images.Fact: Clownfish can change sex during their lifetime.

Images.Name: Swordfish
Images.Fact: Rarely preyed on by other animals.

Images.Name: Tuna
Images.Fact: Capable of reaching speeds up to 75 km/h.

Images.Name: Macaw
Images.Fact: They fall in love for life.

Images.Name: Starling
Images.Fact: Can mimic sounds like human speech.

Images.Name: Penguin
Images.Fact: Male penguins gift female penguins with rocks to woo them.

Images.Name: Turtle
Images.Fact: Their shell is part of its skeleton, made of over 50 bones.

Images.Name: Iguana
Images.Fact: Iguanas have a third eye.

Images.Name: Alligator
Images.Fact: Their sex is determined by temperature.

Images.Name: Frog
Images.Fact: A frog cannot keep its eyes open when eating.

Images.Name: Salamander
Images.Fact: Earliest salamander species lived before the dinosaurs.

Images.Name: Rhyacotriton
Images.Fact: Females often only produce a few eggs each year.

Images.Name: Boring sponge
Images.Fact: Can create small tunnels in rocks and shells.

Images.Name: Tube sponge
Images.Fact: Can reach 50 cm.

Images.Name: Calyx sponge
Images.Fact: Their diameter can reach 20 cm.

Images.Name: Moon jellyfish
Images.Fact: When food is limited, they can shrink to 1/10 of their size to save energy.

Images.Name: Brain coral
Images.Fact: Can live for up to 900 years.

Images.Name: Giant sea anemone
Images.Fact: Often found hosting clownfish for mutual protection.

Images.Name: Acropora
Images.Fact: Develops in the shape of sunshades.

Images.Name: Elkhorn coral
Images.Fact: Can live for up to 5000 years.

Images.Name: Staghorn coral
Images.Fact: Some of the fastest growing reef building corals.

Images.Name: Freshwater hydra
Images.Fact: Known for its ability to regenerate lost body parts.

Images.Name: Green hydra
Images.Fact: Typically 10 mm long.

Images.Name: Brown hydra
Images.Fact: Can reproduce both sexually and asexually, depending on environmental conditions.

Images.Name: Box jellyfish
Images.Fact: Known for its extremely toxic sting; one of the most dangerous marine creatures.

Images.Name: Lion's mane jellyfish
Images.Fact: Its tentacles can reach up to 36 meters in length.

Images.Name: Deep sea jellyfish
Images.Fact: Glows in the dark due to green fluorescent protein.

Images.Name: Earthworm
Images.Fact: Can dig as deep as 2 meters into the soil.

Images.Name: Polychaete worm
Images.Fact: Most polychaetes live in the ocean.

Images.Name: Ribbon worm
Images.Fact: Can stretch up to several meters in length.

Images.Name: Planarian
Images.Fact: Lives as long as not killed.

Images.Name: Marine flatworm
Images.Fact: Often found in coral reefs and can be toxic to predators.

Images.Name: Fluke
Images.Fact: Parasitize members of all vertebrate classes.

Images.Name: Ascaris
Images.Fact: One of the largest intestinal roundworms.

Images.Name: Trichinella
Images.Fact: Parasitic disease caused by eating raw or undercooked meat.

Images.Name: Angiostrongylus vasorum
Images.Fact: Aka French heartworm because it was first discovered in France.

Images.Name: Eunice aphroditois
Images.Fact: Lives mainly in the Atlantic Ocean.

Images.Name: Leech
Images.Fact: Medicinal leeches were used for centuries to treat diseases thought to be caused by excess blood.

Images.Name: Clitellata
Images.Fact: Clitellum is a thick, saddle-like ring found on the skin of the worm

Images.Name: Scallop
Images.Fact: Only bivalve mollusk that can jump and swim.

Images.Name: Garden snail
Images.Fact: Have both male and female reproductive organs and can mate with any other snail.

Images.Name: Cuttlefish
Images.Fact: They have 3 hearts.

Images.Name: Honey bee
Images.Fact: Worker bee lives for 5 to 6 weeks, queen up to 5 years.

Images.Name: Tarantula
Images.Fact: Female tarantulas live longer than males.

Images.Name: Mantis shrimp
Images.Fact: Have been known to take on octopus and win.

Images.Name: Blue crab
Images.Fact: Have a blue color on their front claws (tips are red on females).

Images.Name: Japanese spider crab
Images.Fact: Largest known crab, leg span of up to 3.7 meters, it lives deep in the ocean.

Images.Name: Shrimp
Images.Fact: The heart is in its head.

Images.Name: Black widow spider
Images.Fact: Its bite is highly toxic but rarely fatal to humans.

Images.Name: Scorpion
Images.Fact: Some species can glow under UV light.

Images.Name: Daddy longlegs
Images.Fact: No one knows where the daddy part came from.

Images.Name: Millipede
Images.Fact: Curl into a tight coil when they feel threatened.

Images.Name: Pauropod
Images.Fact: They have no eyes.

Images.Name: Symphylan
Images.Fact: Have a lifespan of several months to a year.

Images.Name: Butterfly
Images.Fact: Butterfly wings are transparent.

Images.Name: Dragonfly
Images.Fact: They have nearly 360-degree vision.

Images.Name: Praying mantis
Images.Fact: Some female praying mantises eat the male after mating.

Images.Name: Starfish
Images.Fact: They can have up to 40 arms.

Images.Name: Sand dollar
Images.Fact: They love hanging out in groups.

Images.Name: Brittle star
Images.Fact: Can shed their arms to escape predators and later regenerate them.
